details.name: Green Revolution
details.description:
In 1964, despite 17 years of independence, India was still trapped in a devastating food crisis. Self-sufficiency in food production was still a distant dream; wheat was being imported from America since 1959. A massive drought multiplied the enormous challenge of providing food for the poor and the marginalized.
Prime Minister Lal Bahadur Shastri took command. He knew that before he could end the misery, he had to lift the nation’s morale. His answer was emphatic: Self-reliance tomorrow could only be achieved by self-sacrifice today.
He demanded austerity from the privileged. A stark message was sent out on 15 August 1964: 
(CG – 15 August 1964, Red Fort)
Speech: “If millions of farmers of our country resolve to increase the yield of agriculture together as a movement, the situation will change for better.” 
Lavish feasts, the indulgence of the rich, must end, said the Prime Minister. They did. 
Speaking over All-India Radio, the Prime Minister requested every fellow citizen to give up one meal a week. The people accepted, willingly. 
He encouraged homemakers to cook nutritious meals without rice and wheat, of which there was a huge shortage. His appeal was respected. 
The Prime Minister cultivated crops in the lawn of his bungalow as an example in the grow-more-food campaign.
Indians responded to their leader’s call with national zeal and emotional unity. It was a tribute to Shastri’s inspirational leadership.
On the administrative side, Prime Minister Shastri regulated the price and distribution of food grains. Food from surplus states like Punjab, Orissa, Madhya Pradesh and Andhra Pradesh was rushed to the food deficit states.

A long-term answer required more. It was vital to increase the national agricultural output.
He established three major institutions: 
1. The Food Corporation of India, through which the state started sourcing foodgrains directly from farmers, reducing their dependency on middlemen.
2. The Agricultural Prices Commission, which, for the first time, introduced a minimum support price [MSP] for farmers.
3. The Durgapur Fertilizer Factory, to reduced dependency of this crucial input from imports.
4. The Indian Council of Agricultural Research (ICAR), which developed the science for India’s agricultural sector. Scientists taught farmers methods to accelerate wheat and paddy cultivation through new seeds, techniques and fertilisers.
On 10 October 1965 Prime Minister Shastri wrote a letter to the farmers of India and urged them to boost the crop yield.
His slogan was: “If one Maund in 65, then three Maunds in 66”.
These visionary decisions led to what is known as the Green Revolution. Today, India is a food-surplus nation.

details.name: The War of 1965
details.description:
On 24 April 1965 Pakistan opened a second, and unusual, war front. Its tanks and artillery penetrated upto 10 kms in the Kutch region of the Gujarat state. 
The Indian Army retaliated in strength. Fighting was sporadic, but the outcome was decisive. A subdued Pakistan was forced to withdraw and accept a ceasefire on 30 June 1965.
This proved to be the opening act of a larger aggressive scenario.
In early August 1965, Pakistan’s forces crossed into Jammu and Kashmir, repeating their old tactics of invasion through deceit. About 10,000 armed intruders crossed the Line of Control, in an attack codenamed “Operation Gibraltar”.
Pakistan had, once again, underestimated the unity of Indian people and their determination to repel the invader. The shepherds of Kashmir brought the first information about these infiltrators to Indian security forces and helped in the mop-up process. 
The Indian Army, following up with hard action, cleared infiltrators from the vitally important Kargil heights, and secured the Srinagar-Leh Road. In a dramatic victory, the Indian Army captured the strategic Haji Pir Pass. 
Prime Minister Lal Bahadur Shastri mobilized the people, inspiring an outpouring of support for the country’s war effort. Women generously donated their jewellery to the defence fund.
An anxious Ayub Khan, having watched Operation Gibraltar collapse, moved to the next stage of his war plan. 
On 1 September, Pakistan attacked in brigade strength, with armour and artillery, in Chhamb, Jammu, in a bid to capture Akhnoor with its regular troops. Operation Grand Slam had begun. Their objective was to take Jammu and Kashmir.
Prime Minister Shastri sent a directive to India’s Army chief, General J.N. Chaudhuri, to “deliver a befitting reply to the enemy”. 
India responded with a sweeping attack. 
At 3:30 in the morning of 6 September Shri Lal Bahadur Shastri startled a watching world, disoriented Pakistan and shifted the course of war with a remarkable strategic counter offensive as Indian troops advanced through the international border, crossed the Ichhogil Canal and reached the vicinity of Lahore airport. 
Pakistan threw the full range of its resources into what was now the “All-Out War”.
The next day, on 7 September, Pakistan’s paratroopers attempted to sabotage Indian airfields. Most were killed, the rest captured. 
It was now time for a clearly desperate Pakistan to deploy their trump card – the powerful Patton tank. 
Pakistan made its most ambitious move in Punjab. On 8 September, its First Armoured Division, which included 100 of the latest American Patton tanks, and 11th Infantry Division breached the Punjab border and reached Khem Karan, five kilometres away, threatening the road to Amritsar. 
Indian Forces were heavily outnumbered in tank strength, but immensely superior in tactical response.
They took up a horseshoe position at Asal Uttar. The Indian commanding officer at Asal Uttar, Lieutenant General Harbaksh Singh, knew his terrain, full of sugarcane fields. He flooded the sugarcane fields to slow down the advancing Pattons.
At 8 AM on 10 September, Pakistan opened a heavy artillery barrage; an hour later its heavy Pattons rumbled forwards. Their progress became lumbered as many got stuck in the mud. Indian troops opened heavy fire, decimating the armoured offensive.
The valour of India’s selfless, outnumbered battalions remains a narrative of sacrifice, heroism and triumph in India’s military annals. The highest honour, Param Vir Chakra, was awarded to Havaldar Abdul Hamid, who destroyed a total of five Pattons from his anti-tank jeep, and died while pursuing a sixth one.
Lt. Col Ardeshir Burjorji Tarapore was also posthumously awarded Param Vir Chakra.
This was the biggest tank battle since the Second World War. Defeat at Asal Uttar broke the spine of Pakistan’s offensive. Asal Uttar became famous as the graveyard of Pakistan’s Patton tanks. The wrecked Patton tanks became an enduring symbol of Pakistan’s historic defeat.
In the skies, Gnats (to be pronounced as ‘nats’) of the Indian Air Force made their reputation against Pakistan’s American supplied Sabres. On 11 September, the Indian Air Force pulverized Pakistan’s biggest airbase at Sargodha.
Ayub Khan, waking up to reality, realized that his forces were on the point of defeat. He asked China for help.
On 17 September, Prime Minister Shastri, speaking in Parliament, accused China of fabricating stories to stoke tension. But Beijing soon went silent. Pakistan’s generals realized that China was not going to enter war on behalf of a third party. 
Pakistan had been comprehensively routed, when United Nations Secretary General U Thant visited Delhi and requested an end to hostilities. India declared a ceasefire on 22 September. 
In a petty and bloodthirsty display of frustration, Pakistan bombed thickly-populated areas of Amritsar in two raids, killing 77 civilians, hours before silencing its guns. 
The war paused at 3:30 AM on 23 September. Lal Bahadur Shastri and our Defence Forces had stood as the shield of the nation’s integrity. 
“Jai Jawan... Jai Jawan... Jai Kisan… 
Jai Kisan... Jai Hind... Jai Hind”
The political debris of war is untidy, strewn with immediate problems and long-term demands; so India accepted an offer by the Soviet Union to mediate between India and Pakistan. A peace conference was scheduled for 4 to 10 January 1966 in the capital of Uzbekistan, Tashkent.

details.name: The Tashkent Agreement 1966
details.description:
Prime Minister Shastri left for Tashkent on 3 January 1966 with a strong Indian delegation that included Defence Minister Y.B. Chavan and Foreign Minister Swaran Singh. 
Field Marshal Ayub Khan, accompanied by his Foreign Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, headed the Pakistani delegation. 
The chief Soviet intermediary was Premier Aleksey Nikolayevich Kosygin.
Prime Minister Shastri arrived on 4 January, and soon made it clear that India’s sovereignty over Jammu and Kashmir was non-negotiable. The state would always remain an integral part of India. Ayub Khan was left with no option but to accept India’s position on Kashmir. The next morning, Prime Minister Shastri and Field Marshal Ayub Khan held one-to-one discussions.
Thereafter, delegation-level talks began, which continued for 48 hours. When negotiations seemed to have become intractable, Premier Kosygin used his cogent diplomatic skills to narrow differences. On 10 January 1966, the Tashkent Agreement was signed by Prime Minister Shastri and President Ayub Khan.
“We tried to open a new chapter in Indo-Pakistan relationship.”
The Main Features of the Tashkent Declaration were to:
        Restore normal and peaceful relations between India and Pakistan
        Promote understanding and friendly relations between their peoples
        Reaffirm their obligations, under United Nations Charter, to settle their disputes through peaceful means and not use force 
        Discourage any propaganda directed against the other country
        Withdraw all armed personnel of the two countries back to the positions they held prior to 5 August 1965
        Repatriate prisoners of warThe ink was not dry on the declaration, when a tragedy sent India into shocked grief.

details.name: Nation pays homage
details.description:
The Tashkent Agreement with Pakistan had been signed, and Prime Minister Shashtri retired after a dinner for the delegations. He ate a small piece of toast and drank a glass of milk as he turned towards bed.
He was scheduled to leave for Delhi via Afghanistan the next morning. For India’s second Prime Minister, the dawn never come. He died of a sudden heart attack in his sleep.
President Ayub Khan of Pakistan and Premier Aleksey Nikolayevich Kosygin of the Soviet Union carried his coffin to the special aircraft at Tashkent airport, as India awaited the return of its beloved leader with a heavy burden in its heart.
The flight landed at Delhi at two in the afternoon on 11 January.
President Sarvepalli Radhakrishnan, Vice President Zakir Hussain and Gulzarilal Nanda, acting Prime Minister, along with the three service chiefs and a stunned nation waited for a hero, whose humility was matched by his courage.
He had led his country to victory in war and wanted only peace and prosperity for his people. His bereaved wife Smt. Lalita Devi fainted when Prime Minister Shastri’s body reached his residence.
One of the most admired leaders of the nation was cremated on 11 January 1966 at Vijay Ghat, in between the samadhis of Mahatma Gandhi and Jawaharlal Nehru. Shri Lal Bahadur Shastri had gone, but he would never be forgotten.

details.name: Early Life and Political Journey
details.description:
Smt. Indira Gandhi…The third Prime Minister of India! The daughter of Smt. Kamala and Shri Jawaharlal Nehru, Indira was born on 19 November 1917.Her grandfather Shri Motilal Nehru was amongst the finest lawyers of his generation.Under the influence of Mahatma Gandhi, he abandoned his anglicised style of life and adopted Khadi. Shri Motilal Nehru had also served as the Congress President. Her childhood nickname was ‘Indu’, even her toys breathed Mahatma Gandhi’s revolutionary leadership.
Her father, Jawaharlal Nehru, was her most important teacher, who imparted vast knowledge through his experiences, letters and the books he gave her to read.12-years-old Indira Gandhi accompanied her father to the historic Lahore session of Congress, which adopted the Purna Swaraj resolution with Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru as its President. When both her parents were arrested during the Salt Satyagraha in 1930, the 13-year-old Indira Gandhi enlisted to help Congress volunteers. She also studied at Shanti Niketan, where she got to learn from the Gurudev Rabindranath Tagore. Young Indira Gandhi was by her mother, Smt. Kamala Nehru’s side when she passed away in Switzerland in 1936. Indira expressed her desire to marry her Parsi friend Feroze Jehangir Gandhi. There were objections from Indira’s Kashmiri Brahmin family, but the couple overcame all opposition and were married according to Hindu rituals on 16 March 1942. Smt. Indira Gandhi was amongst the thousands of freedom-fighters imprisoned for participating in Mahatma Gandhi’s ‘Quit India Movement’ in 1942. She was later released due to her failing health. Her elder son Rajiv was born in 1944, and her second son, Sanjay, was born in 1946. Post-Independence, her father, Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru, was sworn in as the first Prime Minister of India. Later, Smt. Gandhi moved in as her widowed father’s official host to their new residence in Delhi. Smt. Indira Gandhi also began to expand her involvement in party affairs. In 1959, she was elected President of the Congress Party.
That year, she also played a decisive role in the dismissal of the Communist led state government of Kerala, and the imposition of President’s Rule. Smt. Gandhi was also active in the rehabilitation of Tibetan refugees. In 1960, Smt. Gandhi suffered a personal loss when her husband Feroze died at the young age of 48. Four years later, her father, Shri Jawaharlal Nehru, also passed away on the 27 May 1964.
In June 1964, Smt. Gandhi was inducted into the Cabinet of Prime Minister Lal Bahadur Shastri as the Minister for Information and Broadcasting. On 11 January 1966 Prime Minister Shastri’s sudden demise left the country in shock.
For a brief period, acting Prime Minister Gulzarilal Nanda took charge, however, destiny had a higher office for Smt. Gandhi in store! 
She was sworn in as India’s first woman Prime Minister on 24 January 1966. “I Indira Gandhi do solemnly affirm that I will bear true faith and allegiance to the Constitution of India as by law established.”

details.name: The War of 1971
details.description:
India’s Independence in 1947 was accompanied by partition.Pakistan became a separate Country. Pakistan consisted of two parts, west and East. The population of East-Pakistan, primarily Bengali, was higher than that of West Pakistan, but from the beginning the east was subjugated culturally and exploited economically by the west. The struggle for Bangladesh Led by Sheikh Mujibur Rahman, began as a movement for justice and equality. Sheikh Mujibur Rahman summed up the people’s demand in a powerful sentence: “If you want to see this happen and give equal rights to Pakistanis, then you have to give Bengal their right to live.” But instead of justice, the people of Bengal got more repression. When Sheikh Mujibur Rahman won the general elections of 1970, he was denied the constitutional right to form a majority government. On the historic night of 25 March 1970 Sheikh Mujibur Rahman liberated his nation of Pakistani oppression by declaring the independence of Bangladesh. He was arrested. The Pakistani Army stationed in large numbers went on a murderous spree of targeted killings, rapes and loot. More than four million terrified Bangladeshis fled from this genocide to various parts of India as refugees. Leading to a massive humanitarian crisis. India gave shelter to the refugees in this hour of crisis. The mood of Bangladeshis turned militant. A revolutionary people’s militia - The Mukti Bahini, rose to fight against Pakistan’s oppression. India’s Prime Minister Smt. Indira Gandhi raised her voice to draw the attention of the world, but no power in the world community intervened to save the lives and destiny of Bangladeshis, who were being massacred in hundreds of thousands. “This would never have been happened, if the world community had woken up to the fact when we first drew their attention to it.” India stood by Bangladesh. In the dusk of 3rd December 1971 Pakistan launched its third war against India. With air raids on Indian Airfields at Amritsar, Pathankot, Srinagar, Avantipur, Uttarlai, Jodhpur, Ambala and Agra. Simultaneously Pakistan’s ground forces started artillery shelling in Sulaimanki, Khemkaran, Poonch and other sectors. Prime Minister Indira Gandhi spoke to the nation that evening, saying: “A few hours ago, at around 5.30 in the evening on the third of December, Pakistan launched an attack on us. We all have to display courage, show perseverance & unity. I have no doubt that the victory will be of the people of India and the brave Indian forces.” On that very night Indian Navy commenced Operation Trident. Three missile boats set off from Mumbai, headed towards Pakistan’s naval base, Karachi. They kept changing course frequently to avoid radar detection. While the crew spoke in Russian to mislead the enemy in case conversation was picked up. Karachi came within firing range, a little before 10 PM on the night of 4 December. At 10:43 PM, the Indian naval vessels had their target’s in sight. PNS Khaiber, a Pakistani destroyer, PNS Shah Jahan and a merchant vessel, carrying ammunition for the Pakistan forces, were destroyed by missiles. The intrepid missile boats with their various crew now turn their attention to the Karachi harbour complex which was set ablaze with the remaining missiles. The boats then returned to Mumbai at full speed. The killer squadron returned to Mumbai the next day to a hero’s welcome. It had not suffered a single casualty. In the east, on the same night of 4 December, an epic naval confrontation took place in the Bay of Bengal. Pakistan had dispatched its powerful submarine, PNS Ghazi, to the vicinity of Visakhapatnam Naval Base, with the objective of destroying India’s sole aircraft carrier INS Vikrant. In a blistering counter attack, INS Rajput sank PNS Ghazi killing all its 90 seaman on board. In a single day, the Indian Navy had created history. The fourth of December has been celebrated as Navy Day ever since. On 6 December, Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, announced before a cheering Parliament, that India had recognised the new nation of Bangladesh. But the war was not yet over. India’s strategy in the east devised under the Command of Army Chief General Sam Manekshaw and Lt. Gen. Jagjit Singh Aurora, head of the eastern command, was to neutralize the Pakistani Air Force, attack from three directions on land, set up a sea blockade in the Bay of Bengal and finally smash the “Dhaka Bowl”, the area between Jamuna, Padma and Meghna rivers where Pakistan had concentrated its defence. The Indian Air Force quickly eliminated the enemy Air force over the Bangladeshi Airspace. The ground war had a clear objective: to aid the Mukti Bahini and capture the capital Dhaka. The Indian Army laid siege to Jessore, Bogra, Rangpur, Comilla, Bhairab Bazaar, Jamalpur, Mymensingh, Sylhet and Chittagong. And thwarted Pakistani army at every point as it raced towards Dhaka. Ingenious and courageous tactics were used to cross geographical barriers like the imposing rivers in a terrain dominated by waterways. Between 7 and 12 December 1971 several battalions of the Indian army were heli landed across the river Meghna. On 12 December a battalion was paradropped at Tangail near Dhaka, in what is considered as an incredible achievement. Mi4 helicopters ferried a brigade across the two-kilometer wide Meghna river. The Pakistani Army was not short of soldiers but it was hugely deficient in morale since it knew that it had been outthought and outmaneuvered. By the 15 December Indian troops and The Mukti Bahini were on the outskirts of Dhaka.
The coup de grâce was delivered by the Mukti Bahini’s rocket attack on the Governor’s House in Dhaka. Where the Pakistan Commander General A.A.K. Niyazi has been billeted. The Indian Army was just two miles away. Pakistan’s merciless game was up. General Niyazi who still had over 90,000 troops and requisite ammunition surrendered tamely to  Lt. General Jagjeet Singh Aurora on 16 December 1971. Lance Naik Albert Ekka, Flying Officer Nirmaljit Singh Sekhon, Second Lt. Arun Khetarpal and Major Hoshiar Singh were awarded India's highest military decoration – the Param Vir Chakra. Prime Minister Indira Gandhi told the world that an epochal war of liberation was over: “Brothers and sisters, you would be happy to hear that West Pakistan’s Army has unconditionally laid down its arms in Bangladesh. Dhaka is now an independent capital of a free country.”  Adulation for Smt. Gandhi was at its zenith. On 10 January 1972 Sheikh Mujibur Rahman was released from a Pakistani prison. On his way back to Dhaka, he stopped over in Delhi to thank Smt. Indira Gandhi. Sheikh Mujibur Rahman father of Bangladesh took the oath of office as the new nations first President on 12 January 1972. The war has ended but a formal closure was needed. Talks between India and Pakistan were scheduled to start in the last week of June 1972. Smt. Indira Gandhi reached Shimla on 27 June and reduced a Pakistan’s new President Zulfikar Ali Bhutto arrived the following day. The two leaders signed the Shimla agreement on 2 July 1972. The two nations agreed to settle their differences by peaceful means through bilateral negotiations. Their forces returned to the international borders and the Line of Control. The third Indo-Pak war came to a formal end.

details.description:
The re-election of Smt. Indira Gandhi in January 1980 was one of the more remarkable resurrections in the history of democracy. Her Congress won 351 seats in the seventh Lok Sabha. She was sworn-in on 14 January 1980.
In her address to the nation, She said, “We have only one goal - to build a strong, self-confident, self-reliant, independent India.
Come, let us work together.”

details.name: Demise
details.description:
On the morning of 31 October 1984 Smt. Indira Gandhi headed from her residencetowards her office located in the same compound for an interview with PeterUstinov, the celebrity actor.
She was not wearing the bulletproof vest quired by security regulations. 
As she walked through her compound, two of her personal security guards, using asten-gun and a revolver, pumped 30 bullets into her body, at precisely 9:29 am.
The two were disarmed by other security personnel, and in an ensuing scuffle, oneof them was shot dead.
The surviving security guard who had shot the Prime Minister, was tried andsentenced to death and hanged in 1989.
State radio and television announced her death in the evening news of 31 October.
As soon as the news of her assassination spread, outraged mobs turned violent onthe streets, leading to a human catastrophe. 
On 3 November 1984 the nation wept and over a million people lined the streets, asSmt. Indira Gandhi’s body was taken in a three-and-a-half-hour procession to thebanks of the Yamuna for the final rites.
Smt. Indira Gandhi’s son, Shri Rajiv Gandhi, lit her pyre.

details.name: Early Life
details.description:
Shri Morarji Ranchhodji Desai was born on 29 February 1896 in a village called Bhadeli in Gujarat.
His father Ranchhodji, headmaster of an English middle school, and his mother, Maniben, brought him up in an ethical environment of strict values.
The Desai family had limited means of earning. Shri Morarji Desai used to help his mother financially from the ten rupees he received as scholarship from Bhavnagar State.
In school, he was both athletic and studious.
He learnt Sanskrit, and he studied the great religious texts of Ramayana and Mahabharata.
Shrimad Bhagavad Gita shaped the philosophy of his life, and Mahatma Gandhi, and Bal Gangadhar Tilak inspired him greatly.
In 1918 he received his graduate degree from Wilson College in Bombay. For twelve years he worked as a Deputy Collector at Ahmedabad.
He wore a long coat, trousers and a turban as a bureaucrat.
Shri Morarji Desai was married to Gujraben.
He was tempted to join the non-cooperation movement of 1921, but worries about the education of siblings and marriage of a sister kept him back in a salaried post.
A turning point came on 12 March 1930 when Shri Morarji Desai went to see Mahatma Gandhi's Dandi March.
By the time it ended, he had decided that his place was no longer inside government. He resigned as a bureaucrat and joined Gandhiji.
Shri Morarji Desai went to jail for the first time in October 1930. Later on, he was jailed four times.
Aware of his integrity and apprehensive about his personal finances, Gandhiji once asked Morarjibhai whether he would like to return to government service, to which he replied that there was no question of him leaving the freedom struggle until India had gotten Swaraj.

details.name: Desai Style and Substance,The Nagaland Initiativeand Demonetisation
The Shah Commission, Lokpal Bill Introducedand The 44th Amendment Act
details.description:
The demand for accountability could not be ignored. On 28 May 1977 the government appointed a commission under Justice J.C. Shah, a former Chief Justice of India, to enquire into the Emergency and its excesses, with hearings on day-to-day basis. Oral evidence began on 28 September.
Smt. Indira Gandhi challenged the legality of the commission and did not file any statement.
Home Minister Chaudhary Charan Singh arrested Smt. Gandhi and, following a largely negative public reaction, released her within a day.
A second Congress leader who refused to depose was Shri Pranab Mukherjee, saying that he could not speak on oath without knowledge of the specific charge against him.
The Shah Commission submitted a 525-page report to the government in three phases.
The interim report of the Shah Commission appeared on 11 March 1978 describing the manner in which Emergency had been imposed. A second instalment detailed a largely unknown fact: the growing extra-Constitutional power of Smt. Gandhi’s son Sanjay.
The final report, on 6 August 1978 detailed the torture of prisoners and excesses upon the people, particularly in pursuit of plans for mass sterilization.
The Shah Commission concluded that there was no economic crisis or law and order breakdown by June 1975 which could justify the Emergency, and that it had been imposed for arbitrary political reasons. It added that the arrests of people and politicians was unwarranted, and commented that executive officers had collaborated in implementing decisions for potential career gains. It named officers who had misused their powers because of their proximity to the then Prime Minister.

details.name: Internal Political Conflict, Retirement and Last Phase
Early Life
details.description:
Chaudhary Charan Singh was born in Noorpur village of Uttar Pradesh on23 December 1902.
His father's name was Shri Mir Singh and mother was Smt. Netar Kaur.
He was always proud of his rural roots and made hallmark contribution to land and agricultural reforms throughout his life.
By 1925, he had received a bachelor’s degree in science and a master’s degree in law from Agra University. 
He set up practice, but his preference lay in the maelstrom of our freedom movement.
By 1929, he was active in the district Congress, and acquired a high profile for his role in Ghaziabad Arya Samaj from 1931.
In 1937, he was elected as a Congress candidate to UP Legislative Assembly from Chhaprauli, a seat he held till 1974.
He was imprisoned thrice by the British during the freedom movement.

details.name: As Prime Minister
details.description:
After the Emergency, the 1977 elections brought a heterogeneous Janata Party to power, but along with power came struggle. Chaudhry Charan Singh was given the charge of Home.
The rift surfaced in June 1978 between Chaudhary Charan Singh and Shri Morarji Desai when Prime Minister Morarji Desai asked Chaudhary Charan Singh to resign.
Chaudhary Charan Singh returned to the Janata Cabinet in January 1979, with the elevated status of Deputy Prime Minister and Finance as his portfolio. Instead of restoring stability, this only spurred ambition and factionalism in the cabinet.
On 16 July 1979 Chaudhary Charan Singh, with the socialist leader Raj Narain as his strategist, broke away to form the Janata (Secular) Party.
Chaudhary Charan Singh's support increased in the Lok Sabha. He claimed majority.
Speech: 
The political situation is good, nice and we are going to make a government under the leadership of Chaudhary Charan Singh. 
A secret deal with the Congress was also being negotiated by Shri Raj Narain.
On 23 July, the Congress extended the support and on 26 July, President Neelam Sanjeeva Reddy invited Charan Singh to head the new government. The same day Chaudhary Charan Singh was sworn in as the Prime Minister of India.
"I, Charan Singh, take an oath to God that I will bear true faith and allegiance to the Constitution of India as established by law."
“If the country has to rise, then efforts have to be made. We all have to make efforts. I include myself in that, I include all my fellow ministers who are sitting here that we all will have to make relentless efforts, then only this country will grow.”

details.name: Early Life and Political Journey
details.description:
Shri Rajiv Ratna Gandhi, son of Smt. Indira and Shri Feroze Gandhi, and grandson of Shri Jawaharlal Nehru, was born in Mumbai on 20 August 1944.
He spent his childhood in Prime Minister Nehru's official residence in Delhi, and went to Doon School in Dehradun before going to Trinity at Cambridge and then Imperial College, London for higher education.
He returned to India in 1966. Shri Rajiv Gandhi and Smt. Sonia Gandhi were married in Delhi on 25 February 1968. His passion for flying led to a job in Indian Airlines in 1970.
He was content to remain a low-profile pilot till the accidental death of his brother Sanjay in 1980. His mother, then Prime Minister, urged him to enter politics. Shri Rajiv Gandhi agreed. In 1981 he was elected to Parliament from Amethi in Uttar Pradesh and began his political life as the General Secretary of the Congress party.
His first major administrative responsibility was supervising the Asian Games in 1982, which were conducted successfully in the capital.
On 31 October 1984 while addressing a political rally in Bengal, Shri Rajiv Gandhi received a shattering message: Prime Minister Indira Gandhi had been assassinated. He returned immediately to Delhi by a special aircraft.
Within hours of the tragedy, the Congress Parliamentary Board unanimously nominated Shri Rajiv Gandhi as successor. Shri Rajiv Gandhi was sworn in as India's seventh Prime Minister by President Gyani Zail Singh at 6.45 pm on 31 October 1984.
At 41, Shri Rajiv Gandhi was the youngest Prime minister of India.
Smt. Indira Gandhi's assassination had triggered a popular outrage that manifested itself in terrifying outbursts of violence. In many cities, the fires turned into a conflagration.
While addressing a public rally on 19 Nov 1984 Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi attempted to explain this violence:
“We must remember Indira ji. We know that the hearts of the Indian people were full of anger and that for a few days, people felt India was shaking. But, whenever a big tree falls, the earth shakes."
Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi decided to seek an immediate mandate from the voters. He led Congress to an unprecedented victory in 8th Lok Sabha elections.

details.name: Bhopal Gas Tragedy
details.description:
Shri Rajiv Ratna Gandhi, son of Smt. Indira and Shri Feroze Gandhi, and grandson of Shri Jawaharlal Nehru, was born in Mumbai on 20 August 1944.
He spent his childhood in Prime Minister Nehru's official residence in Delhi, and went to Doon School in Dehradun before going to Trinity at Cambridge and then Imperial College, London for higher education.
He returned to India in 1966. Shri Rajiv Gandhi and Smt. Sonia Gandhi were married in Delhi on 25 February 1968. His passion for flying led to a job in Indian Airlines in 1970.
He was content to remain a low-profile pilot till the accidental death of his brother Sanjay in 1980. His mother, then Prime Minister, urged him to enter politics. Shri Rajiv Gandhi agreed. In 1981 he was elected to Parliament from Amethi in Uttar Pradesh and began his political life as the General Secretary of the Congress party.
His first major administrative responsibility was supervising the Asian Games in 1982, which were conducted successfully in the capital.
On 31 October 1984 while addressing a political rally in Bengal, Shri Rajiv Gandhi received a shattering message: Prime Minister Indira Gandhi had been assassinated. He returned immediately to Delhi by a special aircraft.  
Within hours of the tragedy, the Congress Parliamentary Board unanimously nominated Shri Rajiv Gandhi as successor. Shri Rajiv Gandhi was sworn in as India's seventh Prime Minister by President Gyani Zail Singh at 6.45 pm on 31 October 1984. 
At 41, Shri Rajiv Gandhi was the youngest Prime minister of India.
Smt. Indira Gandhi's assassination had triggered a popular outrage that manifested itself in terrifying outbursts of violence. In many cities, the fires turned into a conflagration.
While addressing a public rally on 19 Nov 1984 Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi attempted to explain this violence:
“We must remember Indira ji. We know that the hearts of the Indian people were full of anger and that for a few days, people felt India was shaking. But, whenever a big tree falls, the earth shakes."
Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi decided to seek an immediate mandate from the voters. He led Congress to an unprecedented victory in 8th Lok Sabha elections.

details.name: Shri Rajiv Gandhi and Computers
details.description:
Shri Rajiv Gandhi revolutionized communication systems through computerization. He expanded the use of computers in administration, which had been very limited till then.
“Development must relate to science, and science must relate to development. It's only then we will be getting the answers, we will be getting the speed of development that we are looking for."
Indian Railways became an exemplary instance of the benefits of technological modernisation. Passengers long used to tedious queues and a black market in tickets were delighted to discover that they could now book seats through a computerized reservation system.
A few political parties began a mass campaign against computerization, claiming that it would reduce jobs and sneering that, computers did not sit well on bullock carts. Their protests were ignored.

details.name: Bofors Gun and the Ganga Action Plan
Demise
details.description:
Shri Rajiv Gandhi was campaigning in Tamil Nadu on 21 May 1991.
The Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam (LTTE) had orchestrated Shri Rajiv Gandhi’s assassination to avenge his decision to send in the Indian Peace Keeping Force to intervene Srilanka’s Civil War.
The leader of the Tamil Liberation movement Prabhakaran was worried that if Shri Rajiv Gandhi returned as Prime Minister after the elections, he would send the Indian Army back into Sri Lanka.
Shri Rajiv Gandhi reached the venue of the public meeting at Sriperumbudur at around 10 PM. And was caught in the surge of the local people’s support and affection.
Dhanu, a suicide bomber, bowed down to signify that she wants to reverently touch Shri Rajiv Gandhi's feet. As he bent to raise her up, she activated the bomb tucked below her waist. That led to the brutal assassination of Shri Rajiv Gandhi.
A young Prime Minister who was the harbinger of the generational change in the country, left the world at a young age. On 24 May 1991 Shri Rajiv Gandhi was cremated on the banks of Yamuna.

details.name: प्रधानमंत्री पद पर नियुक्ति
details.description:
Congress won 197 seats in the 9th Lok Sabha, the V.P. Singh-led National Front had 143 and BJP 85 seats.
Shri Vishwanath Pratap Singh, leader of the Janata Dal and National Front, formed the government with the support of BJP and some regional parties.
He was sworn in as Prime Minister of India on 2 December 1989.
On 3 December 1989 Prime Minister Singh addressed the nation for the first time.
“the voice of the government will be voice of farmers, labours and youth. If power is sword, it will be wielded on behalf of the poor and toiling masses. A nation is not a map on a piece of paper. It lives in the hearts of the people. And if hearts are divided, the nation is divided. We will not allow this to happen. There will be a national effort to resolve Punjab, Jammu and Kashmir, Ram Janmabhoomi-Babri Masjid issues.
We will do our best to ensure the power is not confined to the corridor of the secretarial and its four walls but reaches to the chaupals and the mohallas. We will fulfill the dreams of Rammanohar Lohia and Jayaprakash ji. We shall bring forward the legislation for genuine Panchyati Raj.”

details.name: The Mandal Commission
details.description:
The Mandal Commission had been set up by former Prime Minister Morarji Desai's Janata Party government on 1 January 1979 under the chairmanship of Shri B.P. Mandal and submitted its report to the government on 31 December 1980.
The governments led by Smt. Indira Gandhi and later Shri Rajiv Gandhi, in office between 1980 and 1989, did not act on the report.
The Janata Dal included a commitment to accept its recommendations in its election manifesto.
On 7 August 1990 Prime Minister V.P. Singh announced the most important decision of his tenure: Implementation of Mandal Commission’s report.
It recommended reservation of 27% of jobs in the government and public sector for the socially and educationally backward classes.
The consequent political tremors were felt across the country.
While the backward classes rallied wholeheartedly behind the decision, others led protests and hartals in many cities.
A few days later, on Independence Day, Prime Minister Singh said while addressing the nation:
"Today, the country is faced with dual challenges, separatism on one side and violence on the other. A decision was taken by the government recently that backward classes should be given a place in government jobs and the public sector. We want to give them an opportunity in the structure of power, and decision-making to run the country, make it better.”
Shri V.P. Singh was of the clear view that it is not possible to reduce the 27% reservation for socially and educationally backward classes and 22.5% for Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes.
He proposed to Parliament that the impoverished should get additional reservation of 5 to 10% on an economic basis, irrespective of caste.
He later suggested a further 5 to 10 percent reservation for the economically weaker sections within the ‘upper castes’.
Prime Minister Shri V.P. Singh did not leave anyone in doubt about his commitment to the Mandal Commission. 
“If I had to choose between my faithful goal and the prime minister's chair, I would not delay my resignation even for a moment.”

details.name: The National Commission for Women Act, the Prasar Bharati Bill, Kuwait Airliftand Fall of the Government
Early Life and Political Journey
details.description:
Shri Chandra Shekhar was born on 1 July 1927 in Ibrahimpatti, Ballia, Uttar Pradesh in a farmer’s family.
His mother's name was Smt. Draupadi Devi and father was Shri Sadanand Singh.
His education began in the local village primary school from where he moved to Dayanand Anglo-Vedic (D.A.V.) School at Mau, Azamgarh.
In 1945 he completed his matriculation from Jeevan Ram High School Azamgarh.
In 1949 he graduated with a bachelors in arts from Satish Chandra Degree College, Ballia.
From 1950-51 he pursued his Masters in Political Science from Allahabad University.
Thereafter he enrolled for a Ph.D from Banaras Hindu University in 1952.
As a student-activist, he organised meetings for socialist leaders on campus and began writing in local newspapers on current issues.
EARLY POLITICAL JOURNEY
As a schoolboy, Shri Chandra Shekhar had been enthused by Mahatma Gandhi’s call, in 1942, to the British to Quit India.
As a young man, Shri Chandra Shekhar was deeply influenced by the ideas of socialist leaders: Shri Jayaprakash Narayan, Shri Acharya Narendra Dev and Shri Ram Manohar Lohia.
The radical Shri Chandra Shekhar dropped his surname, which denoted his caste. In 1944, he married Duja Devi and they had two sons. 
In 1952, upon completing his Masters, he joined the Socialist Party and became secretary of the District Socialist Party.
Within a year, he was elected the Joint Secretary of the Uttar Pradesh State Praja Socialist Party. 
In 1955-56, he took over as the General Secretary. 
He contributed regularly to a publication titled ‘Sangharsh’, which was devoted to socialist causes.
A RISING STAR
In 1962, he was elected to the Rajya Sabha from Uttar Pradesh from Praja Socialist Party.
In 1965, he joined the Indian National Congress under Prime Minister Lal Bahadur Shastri’s urging.
In 1967, he was elected General Secretary of the Congress Parliamentary Party when Smt. Indira Gandhi was Prime Minister.
EDITOR
In Congress, Shri Chandra Shekhar became the natural leader of a group known as the ‘Young Turks’ for their conviction, courage and integrity.
They were ready to challenge the party line, if they felt it compromised issues, such as social injustice or poverty alleviation.
In 1969, Shri Chandra Shekhar founded and edited, ‘Young Indian’, a weekly published from Delhi which was forced to close during the Emergency.
In February 1989, it resumed publication with Shri Chandra Shekhar as Chairman of its Editorial Advisory Board.


EMERGENCY
Shri Chandra Shekhar left Congress after Smt. Indira Gandhi imposed the authoritarian emergency in June 1975.
He was arrested under the Maintenance of Internal Security Act 1975 and kept first in Rohtak jail and then shifted to Chandigarh and Patiala jails. During this period, he wrote the acclaimed ‘Meri Jail Diary’.
In 1977, his dynamism and established eminence made Shri Chandra Shekhar the first President of the newly formed Janata Party.
“Colleagues and friends, I am extremely grateful to the leaders of the Janata Party and to all those colleagues who have elected me to this position of great responsibility.”
JANATA GOVERNMENT: RISE & FALL
In 1977, Shri Chandra Shekhar played a stellar role in the victory of the Janata Party and its coming to power. He was elected to the Lok Sabha for the first time from his home constituency, Ballia in 1977.
In 1979 Janata party split and was defeated. In 1980, Shri Chandra Shekhar managed to retain his Lok Sabha seat at Ballia, despite the Indira wave.

details.name: Bharat Yatra
details.description:
Shri Chandra Shekhar sought to organise the political space with a marathon walk from Kanyakumari to Delhi called the - ‘Bharat Yatra’.
Between 6 January and 25 June 1983 Shri Chandra Shekhar walked a distance of approximately 4,260 kms. He walked 20 kilometres a day. Thousands of social workers travelled with him.
Bharat Yatra Centres were set up in Kerala, Tamil Nadu, Karnataka, Maharashtra, Madhya Pradesh, Gujarat, Uttar Pradesh and Haryana.
To nurture people-oriented development projects, Shri Chandra Shekhar identified five critical village requirements:
1.        Drinking water for every village2.        Steps to end malnutrition among children and expectant mothers3.        Education for all4.        Solutions to the problems of Adivasis and Dalits5.        Communal harmonyFor nearly six months till it reached Delhi on 25 June 1983 the Padayatra was a continuous procession.

details.name: Early Life
details.description:
Shri Pamulaparti Venkata Narasimha Rao was born on 28 June 1921 at his maternal grandfather’s house in a village called Lakhnepalli at Warangal, in the Princely State of Hyderabad.
His home was in Vangara, in Karimnagar district where his parents, Rukmabayamma and P. Sitaram Rao, lived.
Their ancestors had migrated to this village from Pamulaparti in Medak and they used Pamulaparti as a geographical patronymic in all their names.
As a child, he was adopted by relatives, a wealthy, childless couple, Ratnabayamma and P. Ranga Rao. He was in Pamulaparti when he married Satyamma.
Rao, eager for higher education went to Osmania University to take a BA degree, and then to Hislop College in Nagpur and Fergusson College in Pune for a master’s degree in law.
As a young man in the 1940s he co-edited a weekly magazine called Kakatiya Patrika, before moving into legal practice as a junior in the chambers of Burgula Ramakrishna Rao, who would become chief minister of Hyderabad in March 1952.
The last Nizam of Hyderabad, Osman Ali Khan, or Asaf Jah VII, filled with delusions of grandeur, thought he could keep Hyderabad a feudal fiefdom even after India won independence from British rule in August 1947.
Shri. Narasimha Rao joined the “Vande Mataram” liberation struggle against the Nizam, which was led by Swami Ramananda Tirth, an educationist, reformer, spiritualist and president of the Hyderabad State Congress; the Swami Ramananda Tirth became Rao’s mentor.
The Nizam was driven out by armed action initiated by India’s home minister Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel in 1948 and Hyderabad became one of the states of the Union of India.

details.name: Foreign Policy
details.description:
The Soviet Union collapsed in 1991, the year Shri Narasimha Rao became Prime Minister, changing the strategic landscape which had been in place since the Second World War, Altering the political map of Central Asia, Caucasus and Eastern Europe and creating new challenges for Indian foreign policy.
Prime Minister Rao protected India’s traditional friendship with Moscow, even as he built new bridges with Washington. He sent a senior colleague, Siddhartha Shankar Ray, as ambassador to Washington between 1992 and 1996.
India-Israel
Prime Minister Rao’s most dramatic innovation was in India’s ties with Israel.
Shri Rao changed decades of hesitancy by establishing full diplomatic relations with Israel.
Look East Policy
A second initiative would reap a similarly productive harvest over the long haul. Rao initiated a “Look East” policy to strengthen relations with Japan, the Republic of Korea and South East Asia. Rao became the first Prime Minister of India to visit South Korea.
During a banquet in Seoul on 10 October 1993, Shri Rao said:
”India provides a market for manufactured products which is potentially amongst the largest in the world. Private foreign investment in India has gone up sharply in the last two years. To take advantage of the new opportunities which are opening up, we would welcome more Korean business to come to India and take part in this process.”
Significant investments were made in India by Japanese and South Korean multinationals as a consequence.
Rao also visited Thailand, Indonesia, Malaysia and Singapore. The Prime Minister of Singapore Goh Chok Tong responded to India’s ‘Look East’ policy by asking ‘ASEAN’ (the Association of Southeast Asian Nations) nations to ‘Look West’ meaning India.
India-China
In an important breakthrough, Prime Minister Narasimha Rao and Chinese Premier Li Peng signed the Agreement on the Maintenance of Border Peace and Tranquillity along the Line of Actual Control [LAC] on 7 September 1993.
The two countries agreed to reduce troop levels compatible with friendly and good relations, undertake confidence building measures and provide notification of troop movements.
They also assured each other that they would resolve the boundary dispute peacefully through friendly consultations.

details.name: Early Life
details.description:
The 12th Prime Minister of India, Shri Inder Kumar Gujral, was born on 4 December 1919 in Jhelum, in undivided Punjab in British India.
His father Shri Avtar Narain Gujral, a prominent lawyer, was also a reformer inspired by the Arya Samaj and the leadership of Lala Lajpat Rai. Public service was in the family blood. Shri Inder Kumar Gujral’s mother, Smt. Pushpa Gujral, worked for the emancipation of women and the education of underprivileged children throughout her life. Both were passionate participants in the freedom movement.
Shri Inder Kumar Gujral was just 12 when the 23-year-old nationalist Bhagat Singh was martyred at Lahore Central Jail for killing of a British police officer, John Saunders.
The martyr became a national hero. The young Inder Kumar Gujral became disillusioned with Mahatma Gandhi because of the latter’s tepid attitude towards Shaheed Bhagat Singh; the Mahatma would not condone violence even in the cause of India’s freedom. Shri Inder Kumar Gujral’s rising spirit of nationalism would not be contained; as a teenager he led a procession of young boys shouting anti-British slogans.
Bhagat Singh’s socialist ideology also left an impact. While in college, Inder Kumar Gujral joined the Communist Party of India (CPI) and became the president of the Students’ Union and the general secretary of the Punjab Students’ Federation.
In his autobiography Shri Gujral wrote, “I began my university-level education in DAV College. It was arduous for me to cope with the change in the medium of instruction. At the school level it was Urdu medium, and the switchover to English came as a sort of a cultural shock. I added to the hardship by joining the science course, which was beyond my comprehension.
As a result I lost one year. I joined Hailey College of Commerce and finally Forman Christian College to pursuea Master’s degree in economics.”
This enabled him to take up chartered accountancy.
Shri Inder Kumar Gujral broke away from the Communist Party when CPI followed the Moscow line in the Second World War, after Hitler invaded the Soviet Union, and became an ally of the British in the war effort. Shri Gujral, however, continued to work alongside the CPI-sponsored ‘Friends of the Soviet Union’ [formed in 1927 as part of the Soviet mobilization of international support].
Shri Inder Kumar Gujral was among those freedom-fighters who were imprisoned by the British for protests against the colonial rule. He was sent to the Lahore Borstal Jail for leading an “unlawful assembly of students”.
In August 1942, Shri Inder Kumar Gujral joined demonstrations following Gandhiji’s “Quit India” call, he was acquitted only after a long legal battle. After university, Shri Inder Kumar Gujral went back to Jhelum to join the family timber business. It was also time to settle down; in 1945, he married his classmate, Sheil, in Lahore.
When freedom came in August 1947
Shri Inder Kumar Gujaral’s father, Shri Avtar Narain Gujral, was a member of the Pakistan Constituent Assembly. But along with the millions shattered by partition, the Gujrals joined the great migration to India, leaving their ancestral home in what had become Pakistan, and finding refuge in Delhi.

details.name: General Elections of 1998, Retirement and Demise
Early Life and Political Journey: 16 May to 1 June 1996
details.description:
Shri Atal Bihari Vajpayee was born on 25 December 1924 in Shinde Ki Chhawani, Gwalior. His father, Krishna Bihari Vajpayee, was a school teacher; his mother, Krishna Devi, a homemaker.
Even as a child, he loved writing poetry, a passion that he nurtured throughout his life. Earning widespread admiration, He was India’s first poet Prime minister.
As a schoolboy, Atal Bihari Vajpayee was deeply influenced by Baba Khanwalkar, who was in charge of training recruits to the Rashtriya Swayam Sevak Sangh.
He joined the local RSS Shakha, and continued his activism on the college campus.
He graduated from Victoria College, Gwalior and completed his Master’s degree in Political Science from DAV College, Kanpur. Mahatma Gandhi’s epic challenge to British rule in 1942 inspired the young Vajpayee to participate in the
'Quit India' movement along with his elder brother, Prem Bihari.
Shri Atal Bihari Vajpayee found an extraordinary mentor in Pandit Deen Dayal Upadhyay, who recognized his potential and gave him charge of the movement’s journals. In 1947 Pandit Deen Dayal Upadhyay made him editor of a new monthly magazine called Rashtra Dharma. This was followed by editorship of a daily Dainik Swadesh.
On 21 October 1951 the eminent national leader Shri Syama Prasad Mookerjee founded the Bhartiya Jana Sangh (BJS). Shri Atal Bihari Vajpayee was appointed as sahayak, or personal and political secretary, a crucial responsibility.
Respectful to his elders and charming and friendly to his peers the young man made an immediate impact on political circles. Popularly known as ‘Atalji’, he became the party’s national secretary in 1955. Two years later, after the second general elections, Shri Vajpayee entered the Lok Sabha from Balrampur.
He entered the Rajya Sabha from Uttar Pradesh in 1962.
After the death of Pandit Deen Dayal Upadhyay, Shri Atal Bihari Vajpayee succeeded him as the President of Jana Sangh at the young age of 43.
Vajpayee ji was among the first leaders to be arrested when Emergency was imposed in June 1975. He wrote some of his best poetry during his incarceration.
He was released in January 1977. The Congress was defeated in the general election of March 1977. The Janta Government was formed.
Shri Atal Bihari Vajpayee entered office for the first time in 1977 as Minister for External Affairs. He became the first person to deliver a speech in Hindi at the United Nations General Assembly in 1977.
“In India, We have always believed in this concept that the whole world is one family. Here we are not thinking about the power and importance of nations. The prestige and progress of the common man are of far greater importance to us.”
The collapse of Janata Party in 1980, became an opportunity for the rebirth of Jan Sangha in a new avatar as Bhartiya Janta Party.
On 6 April 1980 with Shri Vajpayee as its first president. The party symbol was a Lotus.
“The darkness will pass, The sun will rise, The lotus will bloom.”
BJP suffered a debacle in 1984 general elections following the assassination of Prime Minister Smt. Indira Gandhi. Shri Vajpayee lost in Gwalior.
It was from such margins that BJP’s leaders rebuilt the party into a national force.
From just two seats in 1984, BJP jumped to 85 Lok Sabha seats in 1989, Shri Lal Krishna Advani was the President. In the 1991 general elections BJP increased its tally to 119 seats in the Lok Sabha.
On 25 January 1992 Shri Atal Bihari Vajpayee was conferred with the Padma Bhushan for distinguished public service. Shri P.V. Narsimha Rao was the then Prime Minister. He was also declared ‘Best Parliamentarian’ that year.
In 1995, BJP formally named Shri Atal Bihari Vajpayee as its candidate for Prime Minister. The party’s slogan for the 1996 elections was resonant: Abki Baari Atal Bihari.
BJP won an unprecedented 161 seats in the Lok Sabha in 1996 elections; for the first time, it had won more seats than Congress, which managed only 140 seats. BJP became the largest single party in the House; along with allies it had a bloc of 187 MPs in the House, far short of the 272 needed for a clear majority.
Respecting Constitutional propriety, President Shankar Dayal Sharma gave BJP the first opportunity to form a government.
Shri Atal Bihari Vajpayee was sworn in as Prime Minister of India on 16 May 1996. He did not have a majority but, as he candidly told Parliament, he would never do anything unethical to patch together one.
“The game of power will continue, governments will rise and fall, parties will born and disappear. Above it all, the country must stay shining, its democracy must remain immortal.”
For the next two years democracy seemed to be in a difficult test. Two governments were sworn in but could not survive. Necessitating fresh elections in February 1998. This time the verdict was unambiguous. BJP improved its tally to 182 seats and it’s 24 party - National Democratic Alliance won 286 seats, a majority.
On 15 March 1998 Shri Atal Bihari Vajpayee became Prime Minister of India for the second time.
“I, Atal Bihari Vajpayee, do swear in the name of God that I will bear true faith and allegiance to the Constitution of India as by law established.”

details.name: Operation Shakti
details.description:
The Test
11 May 1998
Pokhran Atomic Range, Rajasthan.
3:45 PM
Operation Shakti.
It was a top-secret mission. Prime Minister Atal Bihari Vajpayee did not share this decision with Cabinet colleagues until the last minute. Preparations were ready for early May; but atmospheric conditions became favourable only on 11 May 1998, coincidentally the day of Buddha Purnima. On this day India became a nuclear power.
“Today at 15:45 hours, India conducted three underground nuclear tests in the Pokhran range.”
With these tests India became the sixth formal nuclear power, altering the strategic map of Asia and confirming India’s technological and scientific promise. The world acknowledged that India’s tests had been completely indigenous.
Prime Minister Atal Bihari Vajpayee affirmed India’s commitment on ‘no first use’ nuclear weapons.
“We have formally announced a policy of No-First-Use and non-use against non-nuclear weapons states. As Hon’ble Members are aware, a policy of no-first-use with a minimum nuclear deterrent implies deployment of assets in a manner that ensures survivability and capacity of an adequate response.”
There was instant pressure from USA upon India. Washington imposed sanctions.
Three of the five permanent members of the UN Security Council: USA, China and Britain, opposed Shri Vajpayee’s decision. Australia, Canada, Germany and Sweden joined USA in the sanction’s regime. Russia and France were supportive towards India.
Shri Atal Bihari Vajpayee showed exceptional ability at handling to multiest relationships with excellent diplomacy and unwavering commitment to India’s national interests.
He wrote to President Clinton explaining the rational for his decision, India had to correct the strategic balance with China. Shri Vajpayee wrote:
“I have been deeply concerned at the deteriorating security environment, especially the nuclear environment, faced by India for some years past. We have an overt nuclear weapon state on our borders, a state which committed armed aggression against India in 1962. Although our relations with that country have improved in the last decade or so, an atmosphere of distrust persists mainly due to the unresolved border question.”
Between June 1998 and September 2000, Minister for External Affairs Jaswant Singh and US Deputy Secretary of State Strobe Talbott met 14 times in seven countries across three continents.
This comprehensive engagement persuaded USA that Shri Vajpayee’s decision was a rational correction of a historic wrong, and laid the foundation of future strategic and economic cooperation between the two countries. President Clinton's visit to India in March 2000, the first American president in over two decades, marked the acceptance of India as a nuclear power.
“Two nations conceived in liberty, each finding strength in its diversity, each seeing in the other a reflection of its own aspiration for a more humane and just world.”
“No Price is high enough when it comes to securing national interests.”

details.name: 1999: Crack in Coalition, No-Confidence Motion, Dissolution of Lok Sabha and General Elections, 1999
Operation Vijay
details.description:
In early May 1999, Pakistan resorted once again to military aggression with a full-scale assault by its troops in the Himalayan Mountain ranges above Kargil. A region situated between at altitude of 16,000 and 18,000 ft.
Pakistan had betrayed the Lahore declaration within weeks of signing it. Proving once again its continuing commitment to war clandestine terrorism and deception.
Parvez Musharraf, Army Chief of the Pakistani army was the brain behind this operation. By the third week of May, Pakistani troops had established and trenched positions in the high mountains.
Putting Srinagar-Leh Highway, India’s supply route to Siachin Glacier at the mercy of their guns. Pakistan occupied 132 Indian positions in Mushko, Drass, Kaksar and Batalik sectors.
Since till it was conventional practice on both sides to withdraw from forward positions during winter and return only after the spring pour.
Pakistan gave cover to fresh intrusions with heavy artillery shelling, this was well coordinated Pakistan army invasion. Its troops armed with anti-aircraft guns and stinger missiles.
On 26 May 1999 Prime Minister Atal Bihari Vajpayee ordered the start of "Operation Vijay". A counteroffensive by the Indian Army and Indian Air Force.
“The world has seen this that we want peace. Now the world will see our demonstration of power to protect peace. There is no doubt about the conclusion of the battle. Our victory is definite and we will achieve it.“
More than 20 thousand Indian military and paramilitary personnel were deployed to defeat Pakistan’s aggression with support from powerful long range Bofors artillery guns as a counter to Pak’s artillery shelling.
The Indian Airforce launched “Operation Safed Sagar” with MiG-21’s, MiG-23’s, MiG-27’s, MiG-29’s, Mirage 2000’s, Jaguars and Mi-17 armed helicopters that drove back the Pak F-16s.
On 30 May 1999 while addressing the nation, Prime Minister Vajpayee Ji said, "I want to tell every soldier that the entire country stands with you, every Indian is grateful to you. This whole operation has been thrust upon us. The whole world is watching how our brave armed forces are defending the Motherland on inhospitable hilly terrain and at grave risk to their lives.
On 12 June Pakistan’s foreign minister Sartaj Aziz came to Delhi for talks, and was told, there was nothing to discuss until the intruders went back.
“There would be no discussion unless Pakistan entirely withdraws from the Kargil region.”
The defining moment of the war was the battle on the Tololing summit. On 13 June, Indian soldiers proudly hoisted the Nations’s tricolor on the Tololing peak.
On 15 June President Bill Clinton of the United States urged Pakistan, the aggressor state to withdraw. Islamabad still levering under the illusion that it possessed the military advantage, ignored the American President.
On 20 June, the Indian Army captured strategically important Point 5140 from Pakistani occupiers and raised the Indian Flag.
The battle for Tiger Hill, one of the highest peaks in the area was the most challenging part of the war.
By 4 July, the Indian Flag was once again flying over Tiger Hill. Pakistan had been humiliated yet again by the valor and patriotism of the Indian Armed forces and determined political leadership.
President Clinton summoned Pakistan’s Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif to Washington. On 5 July, Nawaz Sharif accepted defeat. He announced a retreat. On 14 July 1999 Prime Minister Vajpayee declared that Operation Vijay had been a complete success.
By 26 July, every Pakistani intruder was evicted. 26 July is celebrated as Kargil Vijay Diwas.
Pakistan in a shocking display of petulance refused to accept the bodies of its own soldiers. The Indian Army performed their last rites.
Captain Vikram Batra, Lieutenant Manoj Kumar Pandey, Subedar Major Yogendra Singh Yadav and Rifleman Sanjay Kumar were awarded India’s highest military decoration 'Param Vir Chakra'.

details.name: Education for All
details.description:
"It's morning, the bird has fled the nest, and the school bell has rang."
The Constitution 86th Amendment act made education a fundamental right of every child, giving free and compulsory education of all children between the ages of 6-14 years who had been denied education largely due to poverty.
"Kids are going to school; we're getting ready as well; we'll go to school; we'll go to school together."
The government also launched the Sarva Siksha Abhiyan in 2001 to address all aspects of elementary education.
Including:
1. Institutional reforms
2. Sustainable Financing
3. Community Ownership
4. Institution capacity building
5. Thrust on quality
6. Preparation of district elementary education plan
It covered 10 lakh elementary centres, reaching about 20 crore children.

details.name: Golden Quadrilateral
details.description:
The Vajpayee government started an ambitious project to connect the principal metro cities Delhi, Mumbai, Chennai and Kolkata through a highway Quadrilateral. This was the biggest road project since independence and modernise the communication map of India.
“The work has commenced on Rs. 54 Thousand Crore National Highway Development Project.”
Prime Minister Vajpayee laid the foundation stone for the project on the 6 January 1999 with the aim of completion by 2006 but effective work began only in 2001 because of delays in land acquisition and other constrains. The project was completed by 2012 creating a multiplier effect on the rural economy. This was complemented by the Rural Road connectivity (RRC) program.
As the Golden Quadrilateral linked major trading centers. New businesses flourished around the country.
In addition, The Vajpayee Government launched Pradhanmantri Gram Sadak Yojna on 25 December 2000. A 100% centrally sponsored scheme for paved rural connectivity between villages with a population of 500 or more, and those with a population of 250 or more in hilly and desert regions.
Under the Pradhan Mantri Gram Sadak Yojna 6,75,813 kms rural roads have been laid so far.
“Even after 50 years of independence, there were about 2 lakh villages which were not accessible by roads. For the first time, the Center has started the Pradhan Mantri Gram Sadak Yojana to connect these villages with good roads”.
The roads provided access not just to cities and villages, it also provided millions of deprived Indians, access to better education, healthcare, markets and business centers. It created a strong foundation for economic growth. Even today people are reaping the rewards of work envisaged almost two decades ago.

The Agra Summit
Soon after Pakistan’s defeat in Kargil, a military coup brought General Pervez Musharraf to power in Pakistan.
The Pakistan Army had sabotaged the goodwill generated by Shri Vajpayee’s visit to Lahore, but he was willing to put the pain behind him and reach out again to Islamabad.
“I have been telling my friends in Pakistan - we have been fighting for 50 years now. How much blood needs to be shed more? Let us fight poverty, unemployment and backwardness.”
Prime Minister Vajpayee invited General Musharraf to India for a summit at Agra between 14 and 16 July. On the table was a four-point formula for Jammu and Kashmir brought by Musharraf:
 Demilitarization or phased withdrawal of troops;
 No change in the existing Line of Control but free movement across it;
 No independence for the State;
 A joint mechanism for governance involving India, Pakistan and Jammu and Kashmir.
Prime Minister Vajpayee could never accept any dilution of India's sovereignty over Jammu and Kashmir or any agreement which did not condemn terrorism. The Agra summit collapsed.
“As far as India-Pakistan dialogue is concerned, it is India which has always taken the initiative for it. In the space of last 4 years, I have been to Lahore, and invited Mr. President Musharaf to Agra. We have repeatedly said that we are willing to discuss all issues with Pakistan including Jammu & Kashmir, but for that cross-border terrorism has to end.”
The Attack on Parliament
Five few months after the Agra Summit, State-sponsored terrorist groups from Pakistan selected an audacious target for a dramatic terrorist assault.
On 13 December 2001 at about 11:40 in the morning, five terrorists from Pakistan entered the Parliament House complex in an Ambassador car fitted with a red light and a fake Home Ministry sticker to deceive security.
They reached the main building and opened random fire for over 30 minutes. All five terrorists were killed along with eight security personnel and a gardener; 15 people were injured.
Investigations revealed that the perpetrators belonged to the Lashkar-e-Taiba and Jaish-e-Mohammad. The mastermind was Maulana Masood Azhar, founder of Jaish-e-Mohammad. Prime Minister Vajpayee said in Parliament:
“Why Parliament House? Parliament House was chosen after careful consideration. The heart of this republic India is the Parliament, which represents the whole country. I don't think it happened accidentally."
Shri Vajpayee prepared a wide-front retaliation; one target was a huge training camp for terrorists located deep inside Pakistan Occupied Kashmir (POK).
On 15th December 2001, he ordered mobilisation of Indian troops on the Pakistan border, called Operation Parakram.
He promised to uproot the evil of terrorism, pointing out that the attack on Parliament “was not just on a building but a warning to the entire nation and we accept the challenge”.
Operation Parakram was India’s largest troop mobilisation since the 1971 liberation war. As the threat of full-scale conflict between two nuclear capable countries escalated, international attention focused on defusing the crisis.
On 16 October 2002 after a ten-month stand-off, India and Pakistan announced that they would withdraw their troops from the border.

details.name: Formation of three new states and The Jammu and Kashmir Peace Initiative
Poet Bid's Goodbye
details.description:
In his final address to the nation, Shri Atal Bihari Vajpayee mentioned:
"The World has started recognising India, as the world’s largest democracy and an emerging economic power...
No longer wait for Gas and Telephone connection now. Mobile Phone subscribers have increased from 8 lakh to one and half crores.
Software Export has increased from Eight Thousand Crore to Fifty Thousand Crore. Before 2008, India will send its own spacecraft to the moon. It will be named as Chandrayaan-1.
Because of Sarva Shiksha Abhiyan, no child, especially girl child will be deprived of Primary Education. Today there are more than Ten lakh women members in Panchayats & Municipalities.
His personality had many facets: orator, poet, journalist, mass leader, parliamentarian and statesman. He started writing poetry in school; his range extended across patriotism, religion, love, satire and social commentary.
कदम मिलाकर चलना होगा
बाधाएं आती हैं आएं
घिरें प्रलय की घोर घटाएं,
पांवों के नीचे अंगारे,
सर पर बरसें यदि ज्वालाएं,
निज हाथों से हंसते-हंसते,
आग लगाकर जलना होगा।
कदम मिलाकर चलना होगा।
Poetry became the creative nourishment that helped him sustain the dark days of detention during the Emergency. Those poems were later published as Kaidi Kavi Rai ki Kundaliyan.
Further collections of his poems were released: Nayi Disha in 1999, and Samvedna in 2002. His masterpiece was ‘Aao Phir Se Diya Jalaye’:
आओ फिर से दिया जलाएं
भरी दुपहरी में अंधियारा
सूरज परछाई से हारा
अंतरतम का नेह निचोड़ें
बुझी हुई बाती सुलगाएं
आओ फिर से दिया जलाएं
हम पड़ाव को समझें मंज़िल
हम पड़ाव को समझें मंज़िल
लक्ष्य हुआ आंखों से ओझल
वर्तमान के मोहजाल में
आने वाला कल न भुलाएं
आओ फिर से दिया जलाएं
आहुति बाकी, यज्ञ अधूरा
आहुति बाकी, यज्ञ अधूरा
अपनों के विघ्नों ने घेरा
अंतिम जय का वज्र बनाने
नव दधीचि हड्डियां गलाएं
आओ फिर से दिया जलाएं
आओ फिर से दिया जलाएं
Vajpayee ji passed away on 16 August 2018. Tributes poured in from all over the world. Prime Minster Narendra Modi walked beside the cortege on its final journey. Atal Bihari Vajpayee was cremated with full state honours at Rashtriya Smriti Sthal in Delhi.

details.name: Early Life and Political Journey
details.description:
"Glittering Life
Dr. Manmohan Singh Kohli was born on 26 September 1932 in Gah, a village in the Chakwal district of Punjab which became part of Pakistan after partition.
Tragically, his mother, Smt. Amrit Kaur, died due to typhoid when he was still a child, and he was raised by his grandparents Smt. Jamna Devi and Shri Sant Singh.
At the age of 11, he was sent to the Khalsa High School for Boys in Peshawar, where his father Gurmukh Singh, a clerk, was posted.
Academic Brilliance
He was preparing for his matriculation examination in 1947 when the havoc of partition upturned his life.
His family migrated to eastern Punjab in June 1947, eventually settling down in Amritsar.
Dr. Manmohan Singh dropped ‘Kohli’, a caste designation, from his name.
He joined the Hindu College in Amritsar and then Punjab University to study economics at both graduate and post-graduate levels.
His academic career took him from Punjab to the University of Cambridge, where he earned a First-Class Honours degree in Economics in 1957. Meanwhile, he won the Wright Prize for excellent performance in St. John's College, Cambridge. He followed this with a Doctorate in Philosophy in Economics from Nuffield College at Oxford University in 1962.
He married Gursharan Kaur; the couple had three daughters.
Dr. Singh’s academic credentials were burnished by the years he spent on the faculty of Punjab University and Delhi school of Economics.
New Journey
Between 1966 and 1969, Dr. Singh worked for UNCTAD - United Nations Conference on Trade and Development and then joined the Government of India as an advisor to the Ministry of Foreign Trade.
In 1972 he became Chief Economic Adviser to the Ministry of Finance and then Secretary in the Finance Ministry in 1976.
Success at home and abroad
Between 1980 and 1982, Dr. Manmohan Singh was a member-secretary of the Planning Commission, after which he was appointed Governor of the Reserve Bank of India until 1985 where he initiated early banking reforms. He was also, simultaneously, Alternate Governor for India at the IMF.
And a member of the Economic Advisory Council to the Prime Minister in 1983-84.
He returned to Delhi as Deputy Chairman of the Planning Commission in January 1985.
In 1987, President Julius Nyerere of Tanzania invited Dr. Singh to become Secretary-General of the South Commission; the same year, he was awarded the Padma Vibhushan. 
In 1990 Dr. Manmohan Singh became Economic Adviser to Prime Minister Chandra Shekhar.
One of the last decisions taken by Prime Minister Chandra Shekhar was to appoint him Chairman of the University Grants Commission.
Destiny had much more in store for Dr. Singh.
Doctor of Ailing Economy
In June 1991, P.V. Narasimha Rao was sworn in as Prime Minister amid a monumental economic crisis.
The new Prime Minister surprised his political colleagues by appointing 
Dr. Manmohan Singh as Finance Minister to help steer the country out of this economic crisis.
Dr. Singh proclaimed a new model of economic reforms for India known as the LPG, or 'Liberalisation, Privatisation and Globalisation.'
During his term as Finance Minister, 
Dr. Singh skilfully implemented Prime Minister Rao’s decisions, including devaluation, lending his own scholarship and expertise to the process.
Recognition
Dr. Manmohan Singh received a large number of awards for his stellar role as Finance Minister, including…
1997 - Lokmanya Tilak Award and Justice K.S. Hegde Foundation Award
1997 - Nikkei Asia Prize for Regional Growth
1999 - H. H. Kanchi Sri Paramacharya Award
2000 - Annasaheb Chirmule Award
Dr. Singh in the House
Dr. Manmohan Singh's significant contribution to the Congress government headed by Prime Minister Rao was recognised by his party after the defeat in the 1996 elections, when Dr. Singh became a front-bench leader in the Rajya Sabha.
He was first elected to the Upper House from Assam in 1991, and he was re-elected in 1995, 2001, 2007, 2013 and then again in 2019.
Between 1 August 1996 and 4 December 1997 Dr. Singh was chairman of the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Commerce in the Rajya Sabha.

When a coalition led by the BJP came to office in 1998, and remained in power till 2004, Dr. Singh was Leader of the Opposition in the Rajya Sabha.
Oath as a Prime Minister
On 22 May 2004 Dr. Manmohan Singh took oath as the 13th Prime Minister of country.
“I, Manmohan Singh, do swear in the name of God and by law established that I’ll uphold the sovereignty and integrity of India…
"

details.name: India-United States Civil Nuclear Energy Cooperation
details.description:
US had imposed sanctions on India after Pokhran 1 nuclear tests of 1974 which denied India the benefits of nuclear trade.
To free India from these restrictions Prime Minister Manmohan Singh raised the issue in the US Senate during a bilateral summit in Washington in July 2005.
“India’s track record in nuclear non-proliferation is impeccable.”
In the same visit Prime Minister Manmohan Singh and President George W. Bush announced their agreement to enter into a civil nuclear deal.
“It’s not easy job for the Prime minister to achieve this agreement, I understand, it’s not easy for American President to achieve this agreement. But it's a necessary agreement. It's one that will help both our peoples. Again, I applaud you for your courage and your leadership.”
The deal was finalized in subsequent visits and formally signed on 2 March 2006. The administration of President Bush worked towards a waiver from the Nuclear Suppliers Group which would permit other countries to supply nuclear material to India despite the fact that India had not signed the Nuclear Proliferation Treaty.
The waiver was granted. India separated its military nuclear facilities from civilian and placed the latter under the International Atomic Energy Agency safeguards.
On 18 August 2008 the IAEA Board of Governors approved the India-specific clauses.
An Indo-US nuclear cooperation agreement was finalized on 10 October 2008 after approval from the US Congress.
Due to Dr. Manmohan Singh’s diplomacy, India was able to join three major international regimes: The Missile Technology Control Regime, Wassenaar Arrangement and Australia Group.
Dr. Manmohan Singh thanked President Bush and said:
“For 34 years, India has suffered from a nuclear apathy, we have not been able to trade in nuclear material, nuclear reactors, nuclear raw materials, and when this restrictive regime ends, I think a great deal of credit will go to president Bush and for this I am very grateful to you Mr. President.”
